quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We would have 10 to 15 meetings every day with potential customers.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A concrete example of extreme customer discovery volume early on to rapidly find (or falsify) product direction.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I still did not exactly understand what we were going to build, which was confusing, because I was a product manager, so I was supposed to start building it, and so, at some point, it was like, "I have to ask, what exactly are we doing here?"
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Highlights the importance of explicitly forcing clarity on the product thesis when execution is starting without a shared understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We really felt the type of questions change, right? Silly. The call sounded like, again, "How are you pricing this, or when can we start doing a POV?"
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A practical product-market-fit signal: prospects shift from curiosity to buying/process questions (pricing, proof-of-value).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think naturally, as human beings, you have a bias to look for affirmation, versus a bias for what you don't want to hear.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counter-bias reminder for founders/PMs to actively seek disconfirming feedback rather than validation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: hitting 100 million ARR, just 18 months after founding, and then, just under five years after founding, was rumored to be exploring an acquisition by Google for over $23 billion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific growth and valuation data points that frame the scale and speed of Wiz’s trajectory.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: At the time, we didn't really have a solid product yet. We would have 10 to 15 meetings every day with potential customers. I was hired as the first product manager. I sat in on those calls.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A concrete example of intense customer discovery volume before having a solid product, highlighting a practitioner tactic for finding direction fast.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I still did not exactly understand what we were going to build, which was confusing, because I was a product manager, so I was supposed to start building it, and so, at some point, it was like, "I have to ask, what exactly are we doing here?" And that ended up pivoting us around to cloud security.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Shows how explicitly surfacing ambiguity (“what exactly are we doing?”) can catalyze a decisive pivot to a clearer market/problem.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We really felt the type of questions change, right? Silly. The call sounded like, again, "How are you pricing this, or when can we start doing a POV?"
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A practical product-market-fit signal: prospects shift from curiosity to implementation and buying-process questions (pricing, POV).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think naturally, as human beings, you have a bias to look for affirmation, versus a bias for what you don't want to hear.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counter-bias reminder for customer conversations: actively seek disconfirming feedback instead of validation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you haven't heard of Wiz, it's not only the world's fastest growing security company, it's also the fastest growing software company in history, hitting 100 million ARR, just 18 months after founding, and then, just under five years after founding, was rumored to be exploring an acquisition by Google for over $23 billion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific benchmark data points that frame the scale and speed of Wiz’s growth for comparison and calibration.

quotes.topic_title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
quotes.text: So it was like, our days looked like talking to 10, 15 customers.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Concrete example of an intense early customer-discovery cadence that practitioners can emulate to accelerate learning.

quotes.topic_title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
quotes.text: And you finished calls with a good feeling, like the person said, "Oh yes, interesting, interesting."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Highlights the deceptive signal of “polite interest” that can be mistaken for real demand or clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
quotes.text: I still did not exactly understand what we were going to build, which was confusing, because I was a product manager, so I was supposed to start building it, in some ways, go to the dev team and start building it.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: if even the internal PM can’t articulate the product after many calls, the concept is likely too vague to execute.

quotes.topic_title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
quotes.text: And I think that that ended up opening a really deep discussion of, "Okay, wait, maybe we are telling a bit of a broad story, and maybe the person on the other end is not going to tell you."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A framework for interpreting customer feedback: broad narratives can mask confusion because prospects won’t always admit they don’t understand.

quotes.topic_title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
quotes.text: So I think that opened up a discussion for us, and we kind of understood that we were listening in the wrong way, maybe, that we were looking for positive reinforcements, but not really listening intently to signs of deep enthusiasm, and that ended up pivoting us around to cloud security.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Actionable lesson on customer interviews: optimize for evidence of deep enthusiasm (pull), not generic positivity, as a pivot signal.

quotes.topic_title: What real customer pull looks like
quotes.text: So yeah, we took 10-15 calls a day, back to back to back.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A concrete example of the volume of customer conversations they used to rapidly learn what was and wasn’t working.

quotes.topic_title: What real customer pull looks like
quotes.text: We really felt the type of questions change.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic: real customer pull shows up as a shift in the questions customers ask, not just positive sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: What real customer pull looks like
quotes.text: Certainly, the call sounded like, "Wait, again, how are you pricing this? How much will this cost?" Or, "Wait? When can we start doing a POV? How long is a POV?" Or somebody would finish the call, and be like, "Okay, I know exactly who I need to connect you to in my team."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Specific “buying intent” signals (pricing, POV, internal intros) that distinguish genuine demand from polite interest.

quotes.topic_title: What real customer pull looks like
quotes.text: So you're actually, you have a bias to look for affirmation, versus a bias to look for what you don't want to hear.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counterproductive founder bias: seeking validation can blind you to the uncomfortable truth that indicates what to fix.

quotes.topic_title: What real customer pull looks like
quotes.text: If somebody just tells you, like you said, "Oh, super cool, yeah, I want to take this as a good sign, but I shouldn't."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb: vague praise is not a reliable signal of purchase intent.

quotes.topic_title: Saying 'I don’t understand' and culture
quotes.text: Sometimes, it's hard to get the courage to say, "Actually, I don't understand." But I think by now, in my career, it's my favorite question.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Frames “I don’t understand” as a deliberate, repeatable tool for clarity—not a weakness—encouraging practitioners to normalize asking it.

quotes.topic_title: Saying 'I don’t understand' and culture
quotes.text: I think, if you build a company with the right type of culture, in a sense, then it's not a shame to say, "I don't understand, or please explain again."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Connects psychological safety directly to execution quality by making confusion safe to surface early.

quotes.topic_title: Saying 'I don’t understand' and culture
quotes.text: Wiz is a very flat organization, in some ways. It's not about seniority, it's really about driving impact, and everybody can have a seat on the table, and voices are heard.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Offers a concrete cultural model—flat, impact-driven decision-making—that enables critical questions to be raised regardless of title.

quotes.topic_title: Saying 'I don’t understand' and culture
quotes.text: I do think that if something is not easy to understand, then maybe it needs a bit more chewing on it.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counterintuitive heuristic: confusion is a signal to refine the idea/product narrative, not just a communication failure.

quotes.topic_title: Post-pivot momentum and early POV execution
quotes.text: Once we found the right path, it was so easy to distinguish it from the wrong path, in some ways, because we did start getting those strong signals.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for pivots: the “right” direction becomes obvious when strong customer signals show up quickly and clearly.

quotes.topic_title: Post-pivot momentum and early POV execution
quotes.text: But actually, it came back filled a day later, and I remember my lesson being, "You know what? This is actually good. I want to make sure they're committed, right? I don't want to push somebody into a POV, if he is not committed to me at this stage."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Uses intentional friction (a demanding POV intake) as a commitment filter so you only invest in customers who will truly partner early.

quotes.topic_title: Post-pivot momentum and early POV execution
quotes.text: I'm not trying to push something on someone, especially not at this point, and my opinion, not ever, not even today, not even when you sell at large scales. I'm not trying to push anybody to anything, I really want to make sure they want it. I have to feel that want back.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A contrarian sales philosophy: prioritize mutual pull and customer desire over pushing, even at enterprise scale.

quotes.topic_title: Post-pivot momentum and early POV execution
quotes.text: It's like, first of all, when it works, it works, and you do know when it works. And the second is, "Don't be too afraid to get the pull from the customer." It's okay. You need that pull from the other end, as well. Don't push too hard.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A two-part operating rule for early go-to-market: recognize unmistakable traction and avoid over-selling—let customer pull validate demand.

quotes.topic_title: Founders selling before hiring sales
quotes.text: we ended up selling before we had a seller's team.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Counterintuitive go-to-market lesson: founders can (and sometimes should) close early deals before building a sales org.

quotes.topic_title: Founders selling before hiring sales
quotes.text: But we ended up learning so much from that, from us, ourselves, us being the founders, myself, closing the deals, actually going all the way to contracts and everything, by ourselves. We learned a lot, we learned a lot.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: founders doing the full sales loop end-to-end accelerates learning and sharpens the motion before hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Founders selling before hiring sales
quotes.text: And then, when we hired our first sales hire, it was also like, "Look, we sold a couple million of this, so you, for sure, as a salesperson, you kind of give that confidence."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Practical hiring leverage: having proven revenue gives new sales hires confidence and a validated story to sell.

quotes.topic_title: Founders selling before hiring sales
quotes.text: I think, sometimes, when you start building a company, you have this wish that if you can't do something, you're going to hire the right person, and he will be able to do it.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Common founder trap: outsourcing core problems too early instead of building the capability internally first.

quotes.topic_title: Founders selling before hiring sales
quotes.text: It's like, if you can't do it one time end to end, and you're the core, core group, the chances of just bringing somebody from the outside to solve that problem, it's wishful, in some ways, but it never ends up that way.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Memorable heuristic: if founders can’t execute a core function end-to-end once, hiring rarely fixes it—founders must first prove the loop.

quotes.topic_title: Why Raaz moved from product to CMO
quotes.text: In general, I myself, people sometimes ask me about career progression, and I never had a plan for anything. That is just, the only thing I did was follow good people around. That's it. I never had a plan for anything I do.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A simple career decision heuristic—optimize for learning from great people rather than rigid planning.

quotes.topic_title: Why Raaz moved from product to CMO
quotes.text: But many times, we would come to a customer, and they would be like, "Oh, I wish we heard of Wiz, we just signed with a competitor,"
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A concrete signal that the scaling bottleneck had shifted from product/sales execution to awareness and brand.

quotes.topic_title: Why Raaz moved from product to CMO
quotes.text: I think the thing that's convinced me to do it was that, in some ways, I really felt like if, in the early days of the company, finding product market fit is a major block for the company. And then, building a sales organization becomes a major block for the company.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A stage-based model of company constraints that helps leaders decide what function to prioritize next.

quotes.topic_title: Why Raaz moved from product to CMO
quotes.text: B2B products, even the most complex products, people are still people. They still buy it, because brand matters a lot.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counter to the common belief that B2B buying is purely rational—brand can be a decisive lever even in complex categories.

quotes.topic_title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
quotes.text: it's like that in the early, early days when we just started with, I remember, I felt like the heat was in the product kitchen. Because it's like, everybody's waiting to have something, people want to start doing something, right?
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A memorable “heat” metaphor for identifying the earliest-stage bottleneck: product discovery/definition.

quotes.topic_title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
quotes.text: Then they felt like, "Okay, you start understanding it," and now, the heat moves a bit to the engineering side like, "Okay, build it. Somebody wants it, build it, make it work."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Shows how the bottleneck shifts from figuring out what to build to executing and shipping once demand is clearer.

quotes.topic_title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
quotes.text: Now you bring in sales, and the heat moves to sales, because they're like, "Okay, we have this thing, now go sell it."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A stage-based cue for when to prioritize sales: after initial product exists and early deals start closing.

quotes.topic_title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
quotes.text: And then, the heat starts moving to marketing, in my opinion, where it's like, "Okay, we have a product market fit. Salespeople can sell it, but they're saying, 'Give me more pipeline like, 'Hey, nobody heard of Wiz. Give me more.'"
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Defines a practical trigger for investing in marketing: sales is working but pipeline is constrained by awareness/demand gen.

quotes.topic_title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
quotes.text: That's kind of, I've always felt like, yeah, in some ways, I also naturally, I guess, follow the heat.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Actionable leadership heuristic: direct attention and talent to the current bottleneck as it moves over time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Cloudinary is the API-first image and video management platform built for product leaders, who rely on visual storytelling to express their unique product value, who are building engaging web and app experiences, and who understand that harnessing the power of AI to automate is the only way forward.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable positioning that frames AI-driven automation as a necessary strategy for scaling media workflows and product storytelling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: our users share billions of images, video and audio files. Cloudinary's ability to automate our post-production work at scale amounts to a savings of up to 92,000 work days per month.
quotes.speaker: Gil Grossman
quotes.context: Concrete scale example and quantified ROI that practitioners can use to justify investing in automated media pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think bold, build big ship fast.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Memorable directive encouraging teams to move quickly on large ambitions by offloading non-core operational complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Board meeting story and nontraditional marketing approach
quotes.text: I just really did what I thought. I mean, I had a ton to learn about marketing, but what I knew really well was the problem we solved, and I really knew our audience.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Emphasizes a practical marketing foundation: deep product + customer understanding can outperform relying on standard playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Board meeting story and nontraditional marketing approach
quotes.text: So I was just thinking, "Okay, what are things I could do, to start fixing the problem that mattered most?" And that was, nobody heard of Wiz at that time.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Models prioritization by identifying the single biggest constraint (awareness) and orienting actions around it.

quotes.topic_title: Board meeting story and nontraditional marketing approach
quotes.text: Those were just, I was saying, "Okay, I think, in order to do that, I'm willing to take chances, I'll just focus on making a lot of noise."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A counterintuitive early-stage marketing strategy: optimize for attention/awareness fast by taking calculated risks.

quotes.topic_title: Board meeting story and nontraditional marketing approach
quotes.text: But I think he meant, really looking at it differently, just thinking, "Okay, what is the end to the goal of having the right people hear the right thing about my company, ASAP," versus a ton of traditional aspects, of building pipelines and different things they really did not know how to do, at that time.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Reframes marketing as speed-to-correct-perception among the right audience, rather than defaulting to pipeline mechanics too early.

quotes.topic_title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
quotes.text: First of all, I think CMO is a very, very hard role. And also, I think it's a role that is very hard to do without a lot of trust, and without a deep connection to the founding team.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Highlights founder trust and tight founder alignment as prerequisites for CMO effectiveness, not just marketing skill.

quotes.topic_title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
quotes.text: Everything you do in marketing is very visible, and you're kind of touching something that matters so deeply to the founding team, and you are the one representing it to the world.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Explains why marketing decisions carry outsized reputational risk and scrutiny compared to many other exec functions.

quotes.topic_title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
quotes.text: So it's very hard to build that trust, and it's very easy to break it, because one bad ad, or something that one of the founding team will say, "Oh, this is not us, this is not what I mean, this is not the right thing," it breaks the trust really easily.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A concrete example of how fragile founder trust can be—and how a single visible misstep can reset credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
quotes.text: I mean, I really don't know how somebody that does not come from from a security background could be successful deeply, in this type of a role, for a company like Wiz, because it is really about understanding your customers, and it is really about understanding your product. I think that's very, very hard to gain.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A contrarian take that deep domain expertise may be a gating factor for CMO success in highly technical markets.

quotes.topic_title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
quotes.text: When you are a marketing leader, you manage performance marketing, which is a numbers game. You manage designers and brand, and then you manage events and field. There's nothing in between those things that is deeply correlated.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Frames the CMO role as uniquely broad and cross-disciplinary, implying hiring/operating systems must handle low-correlation subfunctions.

quotes.topic_title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
quotes.text: Marketing is quite the opposite, in my opinion. There's no cost to anything, no maintenance to anything, no technical depth, no anything. If tomorrow I post a video on Wiz's LinkedIn page, and I think that video is super funny, and nobody likes that video, nothing happened.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Contrasts product vs. marketing iteration costs to justify rapid experimentation in early-stage marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
quotes.text: In some ways, it dawned on me how opposite those things were, and I was like, "Okay, we have to just use it to our advantage. Let's try everything, let's try everything. I'm trying to make noise."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A simple operating principle: exploit marketing’s low reversibility to run many experiments aimed at awareness.

quotes.topic_title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
quotes.text: And we had the exact same spot we had the year before. I said, "Okay, it's a booth at a conference. I'll just make it the weirdest booth ever, because my goal is just having people look and be like, 'Oh, what is Wiz, right? Because they've never heard of me."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Shows a practical tactic for standing out at crowded events: optimize for curiosity, not convention, especially when unknown.

quotes.topic_title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
quotes.text: I wanted Wiz to have a very positive, optimistic type of brand. So I went all in on, "Scrap whatever we were doing before, which was dark, and go pink, go bright blue, always go optimistic, and focused on magic, not scaring people from the facts, but magic."
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A differentiated brand strategy for a “dark” category: win attention by deliberately choosing the opposite emotional palette.

quotes.topic_title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
quotes.text: And it ended up, the amount of people that stopped by our booth was five times the amount of people that stopped by the year before. It's the exact same space, the exact same investment, because you invest in the space.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Concrete outcome data showing how creative differentiation can outperform increased spend or better placement.

quotes.topic_title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
quotes.text: I just know that I'm kind of okay with being pretty sure I'm going to fail at something, and still attempting it.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A practical mindset for taking on stretch roles: act even when failure feels likely, instead of waiting for confidence.

quotes.topic_title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
quotes.text: So that also makes it easier to move, in some ways. If I think I'm going to fail with anything, I'm like, "Okay, whatever, I'll try," and I think over time, yeah, it releases you a bit.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Reframes career experimentation as low-ego iteration—assuming possible failure reduces fear and increases action.

quotes.topic_title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
quotes.text: my mom really believed that if you're good at something, so that's not where you should invest your energy. She really believed in pushing us to the places where we were less confident in, I guess.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A contrarian development strategy: invest in weaknesses (confidence gaps) rather than doubling down on strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
quotes.text: In some ways, I feel, she always used to say that friction is good. If you brush your teeth, and there's a bit of blood somewhere, then you need to brush harder there. It's that idea, that friction is kind of good.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for growth: treat discomfort as a signal for where to apply more deliberate effort.

quotes.topic_title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
quotes.text: I think she put hard work and courage, in some ways, or friction, mostly, above talent. Talent only gets you so far, but that hard work in the friction gets you more.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization for skill-building: optimize for effort and courage in hard areas rather than relying on innate ability.

quotes.topic_title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
quotes.text: In the technical domain, you can sometimes not understand how far you are from a common person in your market, or a seller in your market. And marketing, in a lot of ways, bridges that gap.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Highlights marketing as the bridge between product/engineering context and how buyers/sellers actually perceive value.

quotes.topic_title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
quotes.text: It's like a multiplier, but the further you get away from the core engineer, than product, then in order for the messages to move correctly, they have to be crystal clear.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Offers a scalable-communication mental model: messaging must become clearer as it travels farther from the product core.

quotes.topic_title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
quotes.text: If you're on the product side, you can often work with things that are fluffy or blurry or gray, okay?
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that ambiguity can work in product conversations but becomes a liability when scaling externally.

quotes.topic_title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
quotes.text: It doesn't have to be crystal clear, because you can kind of go around things, in a way, that when you try to scale your message, you can't. It gets lost in translation. You have to be crystal clear, black and white.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for product leaders: remove ambiguity because what works 1:1 breaks when repeated through a larger org.

quotes.topic_title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
quotes.text: And if you are giving signals that are even a bit gray, fuzzy, then it's not going to work, and you can't expect them to do a good job with it, in some ways.
quotes.speaker: Raaz Herzberg
quotes.context: Sets a clear bar for cross-functional execution: marketing can’t amplify what product can’t articulate crisply.
